new.headline: Ongoing Service Degradation in West US region - Partial Recovery Observed

content.excerpt_text: Starting at 08:00 UTC, we became aware of a power outage affecting one of the datacenters in the West US region, resulting in service disruption across multiple Azure services for a subset of customers.Our engineering teams are actively investigating the underlying issue and working to mitigate the impact.As of 10:45 UTC, we have started to observe partial recovery in the region.We continue to monitor regional service health closely and will share more updates as soon as they become available.

Etymology and characteristics

← Previous revision Revision as of 11:41, 7 February 2026
Line 42: Line 42:
According to the [[Canadian Anti-Hate Network]], writer Dan Collen stated that incelcore draws from "[[internet culture]], symbolism and terminology".<ref name="Canadian2023" /> The genre draws musical influences from [[Punk rock|punk]], [[Electronic music|electronic]] and [[alternative rock]].<ref name="Canadian2023" /> Collen adds that not all artists and fans identify with the [[incel movement]], however they evoke the same themes of [[Self-hatred|self-hate]], [[hopelessness]] and [[misogyny]].<ref name="Canadian2023" /> Collen further stated that incelcore was a musical and [[online subculture]] influenced by the "imagery, attitudes and [[irony]]" of internet [[Imageboard|image boards]] and that references to [[Mass shooter|mass shooters]] were a common subject .<ref name="Canadian2023" /> [[Varg Vikernes]]' project [[Burzum]] and its merchandise is noted as "not uncommon among incelcore fans".<ref name="Canadian2023" />
According to the [[Canadian Anti-Hate Network]], writer Dan Collen stated that incelcore draws from "[[internet culture]], symbolism and terminology".<ref name="Canadian2023" /> The genre draws musical influences from [[Punk rock|punk]], [[Electronic music|electronic]] and [[alternative rock]].<ref name="Canadian2023" /> Collen adds that not all artists and fans identify with the [[incel movement]], however they evoke the same themes of [[Self-hatred|self-hate]], [[hopelessness]] and [[misogyny]].<ref name="Canadian2023" /> Collen further stated that incelcore was a musical and [[online subculture]] influenced by the "imagery, attitudes and [[irony]]" of internet [[Imageboard|image boards]] and that references to [[Mass shooter|mass shooters]] were a common subject .<ref name="Canadian2023" /> [[Varg Vikernes]]' project [[Burzum]] and its merchandise is noted as "not uncommon among incelcore fans".<ref name="Canadian2023" />


In 2020, ''[[Pitchfork (website)|Pitchfork]]'' stated that the term "[[male manipulator music]]" had been used synonymously with "incelcore".<ref name="Cat2020">{{Cite web |last=Zhang |first=Cat |date=2020-12-21 |title=The Year in Music on TikTok 2020 |url=https://pitchfork.com/features/lists-and-guides/tiktok-songs-2020/ |access-date=2026-02-06 |website=Pitchfork |language=en-US}}</ref> In 2026, writing for ''Pitchfork'' in a review for the group the Femcels' debut album ''I Have to Get Hotter'', music journalist Kieran Press-Reynolds stated that the group were not associated with the incelcore genre.<ref name="Reynolds2026" /> However, he described incelcore as a "tragic [[Rock music|rock]] [[microgenre]]," as well as "dour or woe-is-me or stupidly edgy" with lyrics inspired by [[4chan]]'s speaking culture.<ref name="Reynolds2026">{{Cite web |last=Press-Reynolds |first=Kieran |title=The Femcels: I Have to Get Hotter |url=https://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/the-femcels-i-have-to-get-hotter/ |access-date=2026-02-06 |website=Pitchfork |language=en-US}}</ref>

== Military service ==
== Military service ==

=== Wartime service ===
=== Wartime service ===
{{Further|German submarine U-20 (1936)|German submarine U-123 (1940)|German submarine U-565}}
{{Further|German submarine U-20 (1936)|German submarine U-123 (1940)|German submarine U-565}}
On 1 October 1939 Jebsen was promoted to the rank of [[Oberleutnant zur See]] (equivalent to [[Lieutenant (junior grade)]] and was transferred to serve aboard [[German submarine U-20 (1936)|''U-20'']], a [[Type II submarine|Type IIB submarine]], until April 1940 as the ships 1st Watch Officer (1WO) under the command of [[Karl-Heinz Moehle]].<ref name=":0" /> Jebsen later served with Moehle aboard [[German submarine U-123 (1940)|''U-123'']] in May 1940 and completed a total of two patrols with ''U-123'' before being sent to U-Boat commander training with the [[24th U-boat Flotilla]] from January to March 1941.<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":2">{{Cite book |last=Busch |first=Rainer |url=https://www.google.com/books/edition/German_U_boat_Commanders_of_World_War_II/Ag9nAAAAMAAJ?hl=en |title=German U-boat Commanders of World War II: A Biographical Dictionary |last2=Röll |first2=Hans-Joachim |date=1999 |publisher=Greenhill Books |isbn=978-1-55750-186-8 |language=en}}</ref> On 10 April 1941 Jebsen was given command of [[German submarine U-565|''U-565'']], a [[Type VIIC]] submarine, as part of the [[1st U-boat Flotilla]] and would command the ship from 10 April 1941 until 17 March 1942. During Jebsen's command ''U-565'' sank the [[HMS Naiad (93)]], a [[Dido-class cruiser]], on 11 March 1942 for a total of 5,450 [[gross register tonnage]] (GRT).<ref name=":0" /><ref>{{cite web |date=1942-03-11 |title=Ships hit by German U-boats during WWII |url=https://uboat.net/allies/merchants/ship/1423.html |access-date=2026-02-02 |website=uboat.net |ref={{sfnref|uboat.net|1942}}}}</ref> Jebsen was later replaced by [[Wilhelm Franken]] who would command ''U-565'' from 17 March 1942 until 7 October 1943.<ref>{{cite web |date=1914-09-11 |title=Korvettenkapitän Wilhelm Franken |url=https://uboat.net/men/franken.htm |access-date=2026-02-02 |website=uboat.net |ref={{sfnref|uboat.net|1914}}}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |date=1939-10-24 |title=The Type VIIC U-boat U-565 |url=https://uboat.net/boats/u565.htm |access-date=2026-02-02 |website=uboat.net |ref={{sfnref|uboat.net|1939}}}}</ref>
On 1 October 1939 Jebsen was promoted to the rank of [[Oberleutnant zur See]] (equivalent to [[Lieutenant (junior grade)]] and was transferred to serve aboard [[German submarine U-20 (1936)|''U-20'']], a [[Type II submarine|Type IIB submarine]], until April 1940 as the ships 1st Watch Officer (1WO) under the command of [[Karl-Heinz Moehle]].<ref name=":0" /> Jebsen later served with Moehle aboard [[German submarine U-123 (1940)|''U-123'']] in May 1940 and completed a total of two patrols with ''U-123'' before being sent to U-Boat commander training with the [[24th U-boat Flotilla]] from January to March 1941.<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":2">{{Cite book |last=Busch |first=Rainer |url=https://www.google.com/books/edition/German_U_boat_Commanders_of_World_War_II/Ag9nAAAAMAAJ?hl=en |title=German U-boat Commanders of World War II: A Biographical Dictionary |last2=Röll |first2=Hans-Joachim |date=1999 |publisher=Greenhill Books |isbn=978-1-55750-186-8 |language=en}}</ref> On 10 April 1941 Jebsen was given command of [[German submarine U-565|''U-565'']], a [[Type VIIC]] submarine, as part of the [[1st U-boat Flotilla]] and would command the ship from 10 April 1941 until 17 March 1942. During Jebsen's command ''U-565'' sank the [[HMS Naiad (93)]], a [[Dido-class cruiser]], on 11 March 1942 for a total of 5,450 [[gross register tonnage]] (GRT).<ref name=":0" /><ref>{{cite web |date=1942-03-11 |title=Ships hit by German U-boats during WWII |url=https://uboat.net/allies/merchants/ship/1423.html |access-date=2026-02-02 |website=uboat.net |ref={{sfnref|uboat.net|1942}}}}</ref> Jebsen was later replaced by [[Wilhelm Franken]] who would command ''U-565'' from 17 March 1942 until 7 October 1943.<ref>{{cite web |date=1914-09-11 |title=Korvettenkapitän Wilhelm Franken |url=https://uboat.net/men/franken.htm |access-date=2026-02-02 |website=uboat.net |ref={{sfnref|uboat.net|1914}}}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |date=1939-10-24 |title=The Type VIIC U-boat U-565 |url=https://uboat.net/boats/u565.htm |access-date=2026-02-02 |website=uboat.net |ref={{sfnref|uboat.net|1939}}}}</ref>


From April to March 1942 Jebsen trained by the [[25th U-boat Flotilla]] and became and became a submarine instructor for the Technische Ausbildungsgruppe für Front-U-Boote ([[:de:_AGRU-Front|AGRU-Front]]/ Technical Training Group for Front-Line Submarines) from October 1942 to June 1943.<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":2" /> Jebsen was eventually given command of [[German submarine U-859|''U-859'']], a [[German Type IX submarine#Type IXD|Type IXD2]] submarine, and was attached to the [[12th U-boat Flotilla]] in the [[Baltic Sea]] on 8 April 1944.<ref name=":0" />
From April to March 1942 Jebsen trained by the [[25th U-boat Flotilla]] and became and became a submarine instructor for the Technische Ausbildungsgruppe für Front-U-Boote ([[:de:_AGRU-Front|AGRU-Front]]/ Technical Training Group for Front-Line Submarines) from October 1942 to June 1943.<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":2" /> Jebsen was eventually given command of [[German submarine U-859|''U-859'']], a [[German Type IX submarine#Type IXD|Type IXD2]] submarine, and was attached to the [[12th U-boat Flotilla]] in the [[Baltic Sea]] on 8 April 1944.<ref name=":0" />

'''James Henry Spring Branson''' (2 January 1842 – 8 April 1897) was an officer of the Indian volunteer force and a lawyer, who was the acting [[Advocate General]] of the [[Madras Presidency]].
'''James Henry Spring Branson''' (2 January 1842 – 8 April 1897) was an officer of the Indian volunteer force and a lawyer, who was the acting [[Advocate General]] of the [[Madras Presidency]]. The son of barrister James William Branson (1813–1870) and Wilhelmina Jane (née Harris) Branson (1816–1888), born in Madras, now [[Chennai]], India on 2nd January 1842.

⚫
==Family==
The son of barrister James William Branson (1813–1870) and Wilhelmina Jane (née Harris) Branson (1816–1888), born in Madras, now [[Chennai]], India on 2nd January 1842.
⚫
He married Mary Isabella Emerton on 14 February 1859. They had five children together.
⚫
He died in [[Marylebone]], London, in 1897, aged 55, from cancer of the [[caecum]], and was cremated at [[Woking Crematorium]]. A memorial brass is hung at the [[Church of England|Anglican]] [[St. Mary's Church, Chennai]].<ref>[https://www.findagrave.com/memorial/270225605/james_henry_spring-branson Find a Grave : James Henry Spring Branson] Retrieved 7 February 2026.</ref>

==Career==

'''Anna de Beaumont''' ({{Langx|nl|Anne van Beaumont}}; died 1518 in [[Valladolid]]) was a Spanish-[[Kingdom of Navarre|Navarrese]] noblewoman and [[lady-in-waiting]], who served as Grand Mistress of the [[Hof van Savoye|Imperial Household]] in [[Mechelen]], in the early [[16th century]].
[[Don (honorific)|''Doña'']] '''Anna de Beaumont''' '''y Navarre''' ({{Langx|nl|Anne van Beaumont}}; ca. 1430 – 1518) was a Spanish-[[Kingdom of Navarre|Navarrese]] noblewoman and [[lady-in-waiting]], who served as Grand Mistress of the [[Hof van Savoye|Imperial Household]] in [[Mechelen]], in the early [[16th century]].


Anna de Beaumont initially served as [[lady-in-waiting]] to [[Joanna of Castile|Joanna "the Mad" of Castile]], and arrived in her [[retinue]] in the [[Low Countries]] in 1496. From 1499, she became [[governess]] of [[Eleanor of Austria]], and eventually also of [[Isabella of Austria|Isabella]], [[Mary of Hungary (governor of the Netherlands)|Mary]] and [[Charles V, Holy Roman Emperor|Archduke Charles]] (later Charles V), under the guardianship of their aunt [[Margaret of Austria, Duchess of Savoy|Margaret of Austria]], Governor of the [[Habsburg Netherlands]], at the [[Hof van Savoye]] ('Court of [[Savoy]]') in [[Mechelen]], [[Antwerp Province|Antwerp]].

From 1499, she became [[governess]] (aya) of [[Eleanor of Austria]], and eventually also of [[Isabella of Austria|Isabella]], [[Mary of Hungary (governor of the Netherlands)|Mary]] and [[Charles V, Holy Roman Emperor|Archduke Charles]] (later Charles V), under the guardianship of their aunt [[Margaret of Austria, Duchess of Savoy|Margaret of Austria]], Governor of the [[Habsburg Netherlands]], at the [[Hof van Savoye]] ('Court of [[Savoy]]') in [[Mechelen]], [[Antwerp Province|Antwerp]].


== Biography ==
== Biography ==
Anna de Beaumont was born between 1425 and 1456, into [[Kingdom of Navarre|Navarre]] royalty, the daughter of [[Louis I de Beaumont|Louis I de Beaumont, Count of Lerín]] and his wife Juana (Joan) de Navarre, [[Royal bastard|illegitimate]] daughter of [[Charles III of Navarre]].{{Sfn|Anselme|1726|p=292}} Anna was thus a distant relative of [[Joanna of Castile]].{{Sfn|Ylä-Anttila|2019|p=71}} She was named after her paternal grandmother, {{Ill|Anna de Curton, Lady of Guiche.|qid=Q116042645}}. She was sister of the famous [[constable]] of Navarre and head of the Spanish faction (the 'Beaumont faction') in the Kingdom of Navarre, [[Louis de Beaumont, 2nd Count de Lerín|Louis II de Beaumont, 2nd Count of Lerín]].{{Sfn|Moeller|1895|p=13}}
Anna de Beaumont was born into [[Kingdom of Navarre|Navarre]] royalty between 1425 and 1456, perhaps in ca. 1430 at [[Lerín]]. She was the daughter of [[Louis I de Beaumont|Louis I de Beaumont, Count of Lerín]] and his wife Juana (Joan) de Navarre, [[Royal bastard|illegitimate]] daughter of [[Charles III of Navarre]].{{Sfn|Anselme|1726|p=292}} Anna was thus a distant relative of [[Joanna of Castile]].{{Sfn|Ylä-Anttila|2019|p=71}} She was named after her paternal grandmother, {{Ill|Anna de Curton, Lady of Guiche.|qid=Q116042645}}. She was sister of the famous [[constable]] of Navarre and head of the Spanish faction (the 'Beaumont faction') in the Kingdom of Navarre, [[Louis de Beaumont, 2nd Count de Lerín|Louis II de Beaumont, 2nd Count of Lerín]].{{Sfn|Moeller|1895|p=13}}


She was a member of the House of Beaumont, which ruled as counts of [[Lerín]] in southern [[Navarre]]. The Beaumont [[dynasty]] was a scion of the [[House of Évreux]], itself a [[cadet branch]] of the [[Capetian dynasty]], the royal house of [[Kingdom of France|France]], and descended from [[Louis, Duke of Durazzo|Louis of Évreux, Duke of Durazzo]], the youngest son of [[Philip III of Navarre]] and [[Joan II of Navarre]], through his illegitimate son [[Carlos de Beaumont]].
She was a member of the House of Beaumont, which ruled as counts of [[Lerín]] in southern [[Navarre]]. The Beaumont [[dynasty]] was a scion of the [[House of Évreux]], itself a [[cadet branch]] of the [[Capetian dynasty]], the royal house of [[Kingdom of France|France]], and descended from [[Louis, Duke of Durazzo|Louis of Évreux, Duke of Durazzo]], the youngest son of [[Philip III of Navarre]] and [[Joan II of Navarre]], through his illegitimate son [[Carlos de Beaumont]].

Several authors, including Bethany Aram and Nuria Silleras-Fernandez highlight that Anna de Beaumont, played a role in the intricate court dynamics under Joanna the Mad, where various individuals, especially her husband, sought to secure the control and loyalty of Joanna's courtiers through the granting of [[Gift|gifts]], [[Pension|pensions]], and other incentives.{{Sfn|Silleras-Fernandez|2024|p=221-223}}


In 1496, Anna travelled to [[Flanders]] in the [[retinue]] of Infanta Joanna.{{Sfn|Fleming|2018|p=219}} In late 1496, Joana bid farewell to the majority of those who had accompanied her to the [[Low Countries]]. However, Anna, described as being part of the "hard core of Spanish staff", remained.{{Sfn|Fleming|2018|p=30}}
In August 1496, Anna set sail from [[Laredo, Spain|Laredo]] and travelled to [[Flanders]] in the [[retinue]] of Infanta Joanna.{{Sfn|Fleming|2018|p=219}} In late 1496, Joana bid farewell to the majority of those who had accompanied her to the [[Low Countries]]. However, Anna, described as being part of the "hard core of Spanish staff", remained.{{Sfn|Fleming|2018|p=30}}

Line 38: Line 39:
[[Ferdinand II of Aragon|Ferdinand II]], the old [[Crown of Aragon|King of Aragon]], honoured Anna de Beaumont with the [[Order of Santiago|Order of S. Iago]].{{Sfn|Cartwright|1913|p=6}} In 1514, Margaret petitioned the Emperor to permit Anna, who was burdened by the frailties of old age, to retire to one of the Archduke's residences in [[Ghent]] and to receive her accustomed pension and a "good annual sum of money".{{Sfn|Le Glay|1839|p=113}} This plea emphasized Anna's extensive and commendable service to "Mesdames mes nieces," coupled with the perceived inadequacy of compensation for her dedicated efforts.{{Sfn|Cartwright|1913|p=6}} Despite the request, Anna continued in her position. A fellow [[lady-in-waiting]], Marie de Croix, the widow of Charles de Latre, who had served as butler to the princes until his death in 1510, was appointed to assist Anna in her duties.{{Sfn|Moeller|1895|p=184}}

She served as Grand Mistress at the [[Hof van Savoye]] in [[Mechelen]], [[Antwerp Province|Antwerp]], for eighteen years, until the marriage of [[Eleanor of Austria]] and [[Manuel I of Portugal]], where Anna accompanied the archduchess to Spain, in 1517. == Family ==
== Family and misidentification ==
In his [[genealogy]] of the Beaumont-Navarre family from 1909, [[Basque Country (greater region)|Basque]] historian Jean de Jaurgain, states that Anna de Beaumont died "unmarried".<ref>{{Cite journal |last=de Jaurgain |first=Jean |date=1909 |title=Les Beaumont-Navarrenotes: historiques et généalogiques |url=https://www.eusko-ikaskuntza.eus/PDFAnlt/riev/03/03046062.pdf |journal=Rev. Internacional Estudios Vascos |location=Paris |volume=3 |issue=1 |pages=46-62}}</ref> Some documents attest her heir as her fraternal nephew, Francés de Beaumont.<ref name=":0" />
⚫
Anna de Beaumont married Luiz de Peralta, 3rd Lord of [[Valtierra]] ({{Langx|es|Señor de Valtierra}}), son of Martin de Peralta, Lord of Valtierra and Leonor de [[Rebolledo]].<ref>{{Cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=kNSuB-IxfXgC |title=Revista Hidalguía número 178-179. Año 1983 |publisher=Ediciones Hidalguia |pages=518 |language=es}}</ref> Their posterity is unknown.


⚫
Anna de Beaumont had at least two namesake nieces, with whom she is sometimes misidentified. One of these, Anna de Beaumont, daughter of [[Louis de Beaumont, 2nd Count de Lerín|Louis II de Beaumont, 2nd Count of Lerín]], married Juan de Mendoza.{{Sfn|Licence|2018|p=«loc» chpt. Six: Burgundian Splendour 1513}} Her brother, Juan de Beaumont, also had a daughter named Ana de Beaumont, who married Luiz de Peralta, 3rd Lord of [[Valtierra]] ({{Langx|es|Señor de Valtierra}}), son of Martin de Peralta, Lord of Valtierra and Leonor de [[Rebolledo]].<ref>{{Cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=kNSuB-IxfXgC |title=Revista Hidalguía número 178-179. Año 1983 |publisher=Ediciones Hidalguia |pages=518 |language=es}}</ref>
== Misidentification ==
Anna de Beaumont is sometimes misidentified with her namesake niece, Anna de Beaumont, daughter of [[Louis de Beaumont, 2nd Count de Lerín|Louis II de Beaumont, 2nd Count of Lerín]], who married Juan de Mendoza.{{Sfn|Licence|2018|p=«loc» chpt. Six: Burgundian Splendour 1513}}

'''Anna de Beaumont''' ({{Langx|nl|Anne van Beaumont}}; died 1518 in [[Valladolid]]) was a Spanish-[[Kingdom of Navarre|Navarrese]] noblewoman and [[lady-in-waiting]], who served as Grand Mistress of the [[Hof van Savoye|Imperial Household]] in [[Mechelen]], in the early [[16th century]].
[[Don (honorific)|''Doña'']] '''Anna de Beaumont''' '''y Navarre''' ({{Langx|nl|Anne van Beaumont}}; ca. 1430 – 1518) was a Spanish-[[Kingdom of Navarre|Navarrese]] noblewoman and [[lady-in-waiting]], who served as Grand Mistress of the [[Hof van Savoye|Imperial Household]] in [[Mechelen]], in the early [[16th century]].


Anna de Beaumont initially served as [[lady-in-waiting]] to [[Joanna of Castile|Joanna "the Mad" of Castile]], and arrived in her [[retinue]] in the [[Low Countries]] in 1496. From 1499, she became [[governess]] of [[Eleanor of Austria]], and eventually also of [[Isabella of Austria|Isabella]], [[Mary of Hungary (governor of the Netherlands)|Mary]] and [[Charles V, Holy Roman Emperor|Archduke Charles]] (later Charles V), under the guardianship of their aunt [[Margaret of Austria, Duchess of Savoy|Margaret of Austria]], Governor of the [[Habsburg Netherlands]], at the [[Hof van Savoye]] ('Court of [[Savoy]]') in [[Mechelen]], [[Antwerp Province|Antwerp]].
Anna de Beaumont initially served as [[lady-in-waiting]] to [[Joanna of Castile|Joanna "the Mad" of Castile]], and arrived in her [[retinue]] in the [[Low Countries]] in 1496. From 1499, she became [[governess]] (aya) of [[Eleanor of Austria]], and eventually also of [[Isabella of Austria|Isabella]], [[Mary of Hungary (governor of the Netherlands)|Mary]] and [[Charles V, Holy Roman Emperor|Archduke Charles]] (later Charles V), under the guardianship of their aunt [[Margaret of Austria, Duchess of Savoy|Margaret of Austria]], Governor of the [[Habsburg Netherlands]], at the [[Hof van Savoye]] ('Court of [[Savoy]]') in [[Mechelen]], [[Antwerp Province|Antwerp]].


== Biography ==
== Biography ==
Anna de Beaumont was born between 1425 and 1456, into [[Kingdom of Navarre|Navarre]] royalty, the daughter of [[Louis I de Beaumont|Louis I de Beaumont, Count of Lerín]] and his wife Juana (Joan) de Navarre, [[Royal bastard|illegitimate]] daughter of [[Charles III of Navarre]].{{Sfn|Anselme|1726|p=292}} Anna was thus a distant relative of [[Joanna of Castile]].{{Sfn|Ylä-Anttila|2019|p=71}} She was named after her paternal grandmother, {{Ill|Anna de Curton, Lady of Guiche.|qid=Q116042645}}. She was sister of the famous [[constable]] of Navarre and head of the Spanish faction (the 'Beaumont faction') in the Kingdom of Navarre, [[Louis de Beaumont, 2nd Count de Lerín|Louis II de Beaumont, 2nd Count of Lerín]].{{Sfn|Moeller|1895|p=13}}
Anna de Beaumont was born into [[Kingdom of Navarre|Navarre]] royalty between 1425 and 1456, perhaps in ca. 1430 at [[Lerín]]. She was the daughter of [[Louis I de Beaumont|Louis I de Beaumont, Count of Lerín]] and his wife Juana (Joan) de Navarre, [[Royal bastard|illegitimate]] daughter of [[Charles III of Navarre]].{{Sfn|Anselme|1726|p=292}} Anna was thus a distant relative of [[Joanna of Castile]].{{Sfn|Ylä-Anttila|2019|p=71}} She was named after her paternal grandmother, {{Ill|Anna de Curton, Lady of Guiche.|qid=Q116042645}}. She was sister of the famous [[constable]] of Navarre and head of the Spanish faction (the 'Beaumont faction') in the Kingdom of Navarre, [[Louis de Beaumont, 2nd Count de Lerín|Louis II de Beaumont, 2nd Count of Lerín]].{{Sfn|Moeller|1895|p=13}}


She was a member of the House of Beaumont, which ruled as counts of [[Lerín]] in southern [[Navarre]]. The Beaumont [[dynasty]] was a scion of the [[House of Évreux]], itself a [[cadet branch]] of the [[Capetian dynasty]], the royal house of [[Kingdom of France|France]], and descended from [[Louis, Duke of Durazzo|Louis of Évreux, Duke of Durazzo]], the youngest son of [[Philip III of Navarre]] and [[Joan II of Navarre]], through his illegitimate son [[Carlos de Beaumont]].
She was a member of the House of Beaumont, which ruled as counts of [[Lerín]] in southern [[Navarre]]. The Beaumont [[dynasty]] was a scion of the [[House of Évreux]], itself a [[cadet branch]] of the [[Capetian dynasty]], the royal house of [[Kingdom of France|France]], and descended from [[Louis, Duke of Durazzo|Louis of Évreux, Duke of Durazzo]], the youngest son of [[Philip III of Navarre]] and [[Joan II of Navarre]], through his illegitimate son [[Carlos de Beaumont]].

Several authors, including Bethany Aram and Nuria Silleras-Fernandez highlight that Anna de Beaumont, played a role in the intricate court dynamics under Joanna the Mad, where various individuals, especially her husband, sought to secure the control and loyalty of Joanna's courtiers through the granting of [[Gift|gifts]], [[Pension|pensions]], and other incentives.{{Sfn|Silleras-Fernandez|2024|p=221-223}}
Several authors, including Bethany Aram and Nuria Silleras-Fernandez highlight that Anna de Beaumont, played a role in the intricate court dynamics under Joanna the Mad, where various individuals, especially her husband, sought to secure the control and loyalty of Joanna's courtiers through the granting of [[Gift|gifts]], [[Pension|pensions]], and other incentives.{{Sfn|Silleras-Fernandez|2024|p=221-223}}


In 1496, Anna travelled to [[Flanders]] in the [[retinue]] of Infanta Joanna.{{Sfn|Fleming|2018|p=219}} In late 1496, Joana bid farewell to the majority of those who had accompanied her to the [[Low Countries]]. However, Anna, described as being part of the "hard core of Spanish staff", remained.{{Sfn|Fleming|2018|p=30}}
In August 1496, Anna set sail from [[Laredo, Spain|Laredo]] and travelled to [[Flanders]] in the [[retinue]] of Infanta Joanna.{{Sfn|Fleming|2018|p=219}} In late 1496, Joana bid farewell to the majority of those who had accompanied her to the [[Low Countries]]. However, Anna, described as being part of the "hard core of Spanish staff", remained.{{Sfn|Fleming|2018|p=30}}


=== Grand Mistress of the imperial children ===

Line 38: Line 39:
[[Ferdinand II of Aragon|Ferdinand II]], the old [[Crown of Aragon|King of Aragon]], honoured Anna de Beaumont with the [[Order of Santiago|Order of S. Iago]].{{Sfn|Cartwright|1913|p=6}} In 1514, Margaret petitioned the Emperor to permit Anna, who was burdened by the frailties of old age, to retire to one of the Archduke's residences in [[Ghent]] and to receive her accustomed pension and a "good annual sum of money".{{Sfn|Le Glay|1839|p=113}} This plea emphasized Anna's extensive and commendable service to "Mesdames mes nieces," coupled with the perceived inadequacy of compensation for her dedicated efforts.{{Sfn|Cartwright|1913|p=6}} Despite the request, Anna continued in her position. A fellow [[lady-in-waiting]], Marie de Croix, the widow of Charles de Latre, who had served as butler to the princes until his death in 1510, was appointed to assist Anna in her duties.{{Sfn|Moeller|1895|p=184}}

She served as Grand Mistress at the [[Hof van Savoye]] in [[Mechelen]], [[Antwerp Province|Antwerp]], for eighteen years, until the marriage of [[Eleanor of Austria]] and [[Manuel I of Portugal]], where Anna accompanied the archduchess to Spain, in 1517. Here she obtained her retirement and was rewarded a pension of 1500 [[Ducat|ducats]] by [[Charles V, Holy Roman Emperor|Charles V]],{{Sfn|Moeller|1895|p=184}} "so that she might withdraw to her home".<ref name=":0">{{Cite journal |last=Martín |first=Luis Fernández |date=1979 |title=En torno a la Batalla de Noain |trans-title=About the Battle of Noain |url=https://www.culturanavarra.es/uploads/files/RPVIANAnro-0156-0157-pagina0375.pdf |journal=Príncipe de Viana |language=sp |volume=40 |issue=156–157 |pages=375-422 |issn=0032-8472}}</ref>

== Family ==
== Family and misidentification ==
In his [[genealogy]] of the Beaumont-Navarre family from 1909, [[Basque Country (greater region)|Basque]] historian Jean de Jaurgain, states that Anna de Beaumont died "unmarried".<ref>{{Cite journal |last=de Jaurgain |first=Jean |date=1909 |title=Les Beaumont-Navarrenotes: historiques et généalogiques |url=https://www.eusko-ikaskuntza.eus/PDFAnlt/riev/03/03046062.pdf |journal=Rev. Internacional Estudios Vascos |location=Paris |volume=3 |issue=1 |pages=46-62}}</ref> Some documents attest her heir as her fraternal nephew, Francés de Beaumont.<ref name=":0" />
⚫
Anna de Beaumont married Luiz de Peralta, 3rd Lord of [[Valtierra]] ({{Langx|es|Señor de Valtierra}}), son of Martin de Peralta, Lord of Valtierra and Leonor de [[Rebolledo]].<ref>{{Cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=kNSuB-IxfXgC |title=Revista Hidalguía número 178-179. Año 1983 |publisher=Ediciones Hidalguia |pages=518 |language=es}}</ref> Their posterity is unknown.


⚫
Anna de Beaumont had at least two namesake nieces, with whom she is sometimes misidentified. One of these, Anna de Beaumont, daughter of [[Louis de Beaumont, 2nd Count de Lerín|Louis II de Beaumont, 2nd Count of Lerín]], married Juan de Mendoza.{{Sfn|Licence|2018|p=«loc» chpt. Six: Burgundian Splendour 1513}} Her brother, Juan de Beaumont, also had a daughter named Ana de Beaumont, who married Luiz de Peralta, 3rd Lord of [[Valtierra]] ({{Langx|es|Señor de Valtierra}}), son of Martin de Peralta, Lord of Valtierra and Leonor de [[Rebolledo]].<ref>{{Cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=kNSuB-IxfXgC |title=Revista Hidalguía número 178-179. Año 1983 |publisher=Ediciones Hidalguia |pages=518 |language=es}}</ref>
== Misidentification ==
Anna de Beaumont is sometimes misidentified with her namesake niece, Anna de Beaumont, daughter of [[Louis de Beaumont, 2nd Count de Lerín|Louis II de Beaumont, 2nd Count of Lerín]], who married Juan de Mendoza.{{Sfn|Licence|2018|p=«loc» chpt. Six: Burgundian Splendour 1513}}

'''Anna de Beaumont''' ({{Langx|nl|Anne van Beaumont}}; died 1518 in [[Valladolid]]) was a Spanish-[[Kingdom of Navarre|Navarrese]] noblewoman and [[lady-in-waiting]], who served as Grand Mistress of the [[Hof van Savoye|Imperial Household]] in [[Mechelen]], in the early [[16th century]].
[[Don (honorific)|''Doña'']] '''Anna de Beaumont''' '''y Navarre''' ({{Langx|nl|Anne van Beaumont}}; ca. 1430 – 1518) was a Spanish-[[Kingdom of Navarre|Navarrese]] noblewoman and [[lady-in-waiting]], who served as Grand Mistress of the [[Hof van Savoye|Imperial Household]] in [[Mechelen]], in the early [[16th century]].


Anna de Beaumont initially served as [[lady-in-waiting]] to [[Joanna of Castile|Joanna "the Mad" of Castile]], and arrived in her [[retinue]] in the [[Low Countries]] in 1496. From 1499, she became [[governess]] of [[Eleanor of Austria]], and eventually also of [[Isabella of Austria|Isabella]], [[Mary of Hungary (governor of the Netherlands)|Mary]] and [[Charles V, Holy Roman Emperor|Archduke Charles]] (later Charles V), under the guardianship of their aunt [[Margaret of Austria, Duchess of Savoy|Margaret of Austria]], Governor of the [[Habsburg Netherlands]], at the [[Hof van Savoye]] ('Court of [[Savoy]]') in [[Mechelen]], [[Antwerp Province|Antwerp]].
Anna de Beaumont initially served as [[lady-in-waiting]] to [[Joanna of Castile|Joanna "the Mad" of Castile]], and arrived in her [[retinue]] in the [[Low Countries]] in 1496. From 1499, she became [[governess]] (aya) of [[Eleanor of Austria]], and eventually also of [[Isabella of Austria|Isabella]], [[Mary of Hungary (governor of the Netherlands)|Mary]] and [[Charles V, Holy Roman Emperor|Archduke Charles]] (later Charles V), under the guardianship of their aunt [[Margaret of Austria, Duchess of Savoy|Margaret of Austria]], Governor of the [[Habsburg Netherlands]], at the [[Hof van Savoye]] ('Court of [[Savoy]]') in [[Mechelen]], [[Antwerp Province|Antwerp]].


== Biography ==
== Biography ==
Anna de Beaumont was born between 1425 and 1456, into [[Kingdom of Navarre|Navarre]] royalty, the daughter of [[Louis I de Beaumont|Louis I de Beaumont, Count of Lerín]] and his wife Juana (Joan) de Navarre, [[Royal bastard|illegitimate]] daughter of [[Charles III of Navarre]].{{Sfn|Anselme|1726|p=292}} Anna was thus a distant relative of [[Joanna of Castile]].{{Sfn|Ylä-Anttila|2019|p=71}} She was named after her paternal grandmother, {{Ill|Anna de Curton, Lady of Guiche.|qid=Q116042645}}. She was sister of the famous [[constable]] of Navarre and head of the Spanish faction (the 'Beaumont faction') in the Kingdom of Navarre, [[Louis de Beaumont, 2nd Count de Lerín|Louis II de Beaumont, 2nd Count of Lerín]].{{Sfn|Moeller|1895|p=13}}
Anna de Beaumont was born into [[Kingdom of Navarre|Navarre]] royalty between 1425 and 1456, perhaps in ca. 1430 at [[Lerín]]. She was the daughter of [[Louis I de Beaumont|Louis I de Beaumont, Count of Lerín]] and his wife Juana (Joan) de Navarre, [[Royal bastard|illegitimate]] daughter of [[Charles III of Navarre]].{{Sfn|Anselme|1726|p=292}} Anna was thus a distant relative of [[Joanna of Castile]].{{Sfn|Ylä-Anttila|2019|p=71}} She was named after her paternal grandmother, {{Ill|Anna de Curton, Lady of Guiche.|qid=Q116042645}}. She was sister of the famous [[constable]] of Navarre and head of the Spanish faction (the 'Beaumont faction') in the Kingdom of Navarre, [[Louis de Beaumont, 2nd Count de Lerín|Louis II de Beaumont, 2nd Count of Lerín]].{{Sfn|Moeller|1895|p=13}}


She was a member of the House of Beaumont, which ruled as counts of [[Lerín]] in southern [[Navarre]]. The Beaumont [[dynasty]] was a scion of the [[House of Évreux]], itself a [[cadet branch]] of the [[Capetian dynasty]], the royal house of [[Kingdom of France|France]], and descended from [[Louis, Duke of Durazzo|Louis of Évreux, Duke of Durazzo]], the youngest son of [[Philip III of Navarre]] and [[Joan II of Navarre]], through his illegitimate son [[Carlos de Beaumont]].
She was a member of the House of Beaumont, which ruled as counts of [[Lerín]] in southern [[Navarre]]. The Beaumont [[dynasty]] was a scion of the [[House of Évreux]], itself a [[cadet branch]] of the [[Capetian dynasty]], the royal house of [[Kingdom of France|France]], and descended from [[Louis, Duke of Durazzo|Louis of Évreux, Duke of Durazzo]], the youngest son of [[Philip III of Navarre]] and [[Joan II of Navarre]], through his illegitimate son [[Carlos de Beaumont]].
Line 27: Line 28:
Several authors, including Bethany Aram and Nuria Silleras-Fernandez highlight that Anna de Beaumont, played a role in the intricate court dynamics under Joanna the Mad, where various individuals, especially her husband, sought to secure the control and loyalty of Joanna's courtiers through the granting of [[Gift|gifts]], [[Pension|pensions]], and other incentives.{{Sfn|Silleras-Fernandez|2024|p=221-223}}
Several authors, including Bethany Aram and Nuria Silleras-Fernandez highlight that Anna de Beaumont, played a role in the intricate court dynamics under Joanna the Mad, where various individuals, especially her husband, sought to secure the control and loyalty of Joanna's courtiers through the granting of [[Gift|gifts]], [[Pension|pensions]], and other incentives.{{Sfn|Silleras-Fernandez|2024|p=221-223}}


In 1496, Anna travelled to [[Flanders]] in the [[retinue]] of Infanta Joanna.{{Sfn|Fleming|2018|p=219}} In late 1496, Joana bid farewell to the majority of those who had accompanied her to the [[Low Countries]]. However, Anna, described as being part of the "hard core of Spanish staff", remained.{{Sfn|Fleming|2018|p=30}}
In August 1496, Anna set sail from [[Laredo, Spain|Laredo]] and travelled to [[Flanders]] in the [[retinue]] of Infanta Joanna.{{Sfn|Fleming|2018|p=219}} In late 1496, Joana bid farewell to the majority of those who had accompanied her to the [[Low Countries]]. However, Anna, described as being part of the "hard core of Spanish staff", remained.{{Sfn|Fleming|2018|p=30}}


=== Grand Mistress of the imperial children ===
=== Grand Mistress of the imperial children ===
Line 38: Line 39:
[[Ferdinand II of Aragon|Ferdinand II]], the old [[Crown of Aragon|King of Aragon]], honoured Anna de Beaumont with the [[Order of Santiago|Order of S. Iago]].{{Sfn|Cartwright|1913|p=6}} In 1514, Margaret petitioned the Emperor to permit Anna, who was burdened by the frailties of old age, to retire to one of the Archduke's residences in [[Ghent]] and to receive her accustomed pension and a "good annual sum of money".{{Sfn|Le Glay|1839|p=113}} This plea emphasized Anna's extensive and commendable service to "Mesdames mes nieces," coupled with the perceived inadequacy of compensation for her dedicated efforts.{{Sfn|Cartwright|1913|p=6}} Despite the request, Anna continued in her position. A fellow [[lady-in-waiting]], Marie de Croix, the widow of Charles de Latre, who had served as butler to the princes until his death in 1510, was appointed to assist Anna in her duties.{{Sfn|Moeller|1895|p=184}}
[[Ferdinand II of Aragon|Ferdinand II]], the old [[Crown of Aragon|King of Aragon]], honoured Anna de Beaumont with the [[Order of Santiago|Order of S. Iago]].{{Sfn|Cartwright|1913|p=6}} In 1514, Margaret petitioned the Emperor to permit Anna, who was burdened by the frailties of old age, to retire to one of the Archduke's residences in [[Ghent]] and to receive her accustomed pension and a "good annual sum of money".{{Sfn|Le Glay|1839|p=113}} This plea emphasized Anna's extensive and commendable service to "Mesdames mes nieces," coupled with the perceived inadequacy of compensation for her dedicated efforts.{{Sfn|Cartwright|1913|p=6}} Despite the request, Anna continued in her position. A fellow [[lady-in-waiting]], Marie de Croix, the widow of Charles de Latre, who had served as butler to the princes until his death in 1510, was appointed to assist Anna in her duties.{{Sfn|Moeller|1895|p=184}}


She served as Grand Mistress at the [[Hof van Savoye]] in [[Mechelen]], [[Antwerp Province|Antwerp]], for eighteen years, until the marriage of [[Eleanor of Austria]] and [[Manuel I of Portugal]], where Anna accompanied the archduchess to Spain, in 1517. Here she obtained her retirement and was rewarded a pension of 1500 [[Ducat|ducats]].{{Sfn|Moeller|1895|p=184}}
She served as Grand Mistress at the [[Hof van Savoye]] in [[Mechelen]], [[Antwerp Province|Antwerp]], for eighteen years, until the marriage of [[Eleanor of Austria]] and [[Manuel I of Portugal]], where Anna accompanied the archduchess to Spain, in 1517. Here she obtained her retirement and was rewarded a pension of 1500 [[Ducat|ducats]] by [[Charles V, Holy Roman Emperor|Charles V]],{{Sfn|Moeller|1895|p=184}} "so that she might withdraw to her home".<ref name=":0">{{Cite journal |last=Martín |first=Luis Fernández |date=1979 |title=En torno a la Batalla de Noain |trans-title=About the Battle of Noain |url=https://www.culturanavarra.es/uploads/files/RPVIANAnro-0156-0157-pagina0375.pdf |journal=Príncipe de Viana |language=sp |volume=40 |issue=156–157 |pages=375-422 |issn=0032-8472}}</ref>


She died shortly afterwards in 1518 in [[Valladolid]].{{Sfn|Moeller|1895|p=184}}
She died shortly afterwards in 1518 in [[Valladolid]].{{Sfn|Moeller|1895|p=184}}


== Family ==
== Family and misidentification ==
In his [[genealogy]] of the Beaumont-Navarre family from 1909, [[Basque Country (greater region)|Basque]] historian Jean de Jaurgain, states that Anna de Beaumont died "unmarried".<ref>{{Cite journal |last=de Jaurgain |first=Jean |date=1909 |title=Les Beaumont-Navarrenotes: historiques et généalogiques |url=https://www.eusko-ikaskuntza.eus/PDFAnlt/riev/03/03046062.pdf |journal=Rev. Internacional Estudios Vascos |location=Paris |volume=3 |issue=1 |pages=46-62}}</ref> Some documents attest her heir as her fraternal nephew, Francés de Beaumont.<ref name=":0" />
⚫
Anna de Beaumont married Luiz de Peralta, 3rd Lord of [[Valtierra]] ({{Langx|es|Señor de Valtierra}}), son of Martin de Peralta, Lord of Valtierra and Leonor de [[Rebolledo]].<ref>{{Cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=kNSuB-IxfXgC |title=Revista Hidalguía número 178-179. Año 1983 |publisher=Ediciones Hidalguia |pages=518 |language=es}}</ref> Their posterity is unknown.


⚫
Anna de Beaumont had at least two namesake nieces, with whom she is sometimes misidentified. One of these, Anna de Beaumont, daughter of [[Louis de Beaumont, 2nd Count de Lerín|Louis II de Beaumont, 2nd Count of Lerín]], married Juan de Mendoza.{{Sfn|Licence|2018|p=«loc» chpt. Six: Burgundian Splendour 1513}} Her brother, Juan de Beaumont, also had a daughter named Ana de Beaumont, who married Luiz de Peralta, 3rd Lord of [[Valtierra]] ({{Langx|es|Señor de Valtierra}}), son of Martin de Peralta, Lord of Valtierra and Leonor de [[Rebolledo]].<ref>{{Cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=kNSuB-IxfXgC |title=Revista Hidalguía número 178-179. Año 1983 |publisher=Ediciones Hidalguia |pages=518 |language=es}}</ref>
== Misidentification ==
Anna de Beaumont is sometimes misidentified with her namesake niece, Anna de Beaumont, daughter of [[Louis de Beaumont, 2nd Count de Lerín|Louis II de Beaumont, 2nd Count of Lerín]], who married Juan de Mendoza.{{Sfn|Licence|2018|p=«loc» chpt. Six: Burgundian Splendour 1513}}

'''RML ''497''''' (Rescue Motor Launch number 497<ref name="GreenwayProject">{{cite web|url=http://greenwayferry.co.uk/2012/2013/04/19/fairmile-rml497-project-western-lady-iii/|title=Fairmile B – RML497 – Project|date=19 April 2013|publisher=Greenway Ferry Pleasure Cruises|access-date=5 May 2013}}</ref>) is a former [[Royal Navy]] [[Fairmile B motor launch]] from [[World War II]]. She was named '''''Western Lady III''''' on her entry to civilian service, as a passenger motor vessel for [[Western Lady Ferry Service]]. From 2009<ref>{{Cite web |title=Back in port – the 'Lady' who 'should never have left' |url=http://www.torquayheraldexpress.co.uk/port-8212-Lady-left/story-12350835-detail/story.html |work=Torquay Herald Express |access-date=20 December 2015}}</ref> to 2015, she operated as '''''The Fairmile''''' for [[Greenway Ferry]] on their day cruise route from [[Torquay]] and [[Brixham]] to [[Dartmouth, Devon|Dartmouth]] and [[Greenway Estate|Greenway]].<ref name="Simplon">{{cite web| author=Boyfrom le, I| url=http://www.simplonpc.co.uk/GreenwayFerry.html#TheFairmile.html| title=Greenway Ferry| publisher=Simplon Postcards| access-date=6 November 2009}}</ref> In May 2013, she was returned to her original wartime appearance. Torbay's "ferry wars"{{clarify}}} forced her removal from service,<ref>{{Cite web |title=Torbay ferry wars scupper service |url=http://www.torquayheraldexpress.co.uk/Bay-ferry-wars-scupper-service/story-26899092-detail/story.html |work=[[Torquay Herald Express]] |access-date= 20 December 2015 }}</ref> and in December 2015, RML ''497'' was acquired by the [[National Museum of the Royal Navy]].
'''RML ''497''''' (Rescue Motor Launch number 497<ref name="GreenwayProject">{{cite web|url=http://greenwayferry.co.uk/2012/2013/04/19/fairmile-rml497-project-western-lady-iii/|title=Fairmile B – RML497 – Project|date=19 April 2013|publisher=Greenway Ferry Pleasure Cruises|access-date=5 May 2013}}</ref>) is a former [[Royal Navy]] [[Fairmile B motor launch]] from [[World War II]]. She was named '''''Western Lady III''''' on her entry to civilian service, as a passenger motor vessel for [[Western Lady Ferry Service]]. From 2009<ref>{{Cite web |title=Back in port – the 'Lady' who 'should never have left' |url=http://www.torquayheraldexpress.co.uk/port-8212-Lady-left/story-12350835-detail/story.html |work=Torquay Herald Express |access-date=20 December 2015}}</ref> to 2015, she operated as '''''The Fairmile''''' for [[Greenway Ferry]] on their day cruise route from [[Torquay]] and [[Brixham]] to [[Dartmouth, Devon|Dartmouth]] and [[Greenway Estate|Greenway]].<ref name="Simplon">{{cite web| author=Boyfrom le, I| url=http://www.simplonpc.co.uk/GreenwayFerry.html#TheFairmile.html| title=Greenway Ferry| publisher=Simplon Postcards| access-date=6 November 2009}}</ref> In May 2013, she was returned to her original wartime appearance. Torbay's "ferry wars"{{clarify|date=February 2026}}} forced her removal from service,<ref>{{Cite web |title=Torbay ferry wars scupper service |url=http://www.torquayheraldexpress.co.uk/Bay-ferry-wars-scupper-service/story-26899092-detail/story.html |work=[[Torquay Herald Express]] |access-date= 20 December 2015 }}</ref> and in December 2015, RML ''497'' was acquired by the [[National Museum of the Royal Navy]].

From 2009<ref>{{Cite web |title=Back in port – the 'Lady' who 'should never have left' |url=http://www.torquayheraldexpress.co.uk/port-8212-Lady-left/story-12350835-detail/story.html |work=Torquay Herald Express |access-date=20 December 2015}}</ref> to 2015, she operated as '''''The Fairmile''''' for [[Greenway Ferry]] on their day cruise route from [[Torquay]] and [[Brixham]] to [[Dartmouth, Devon|Dartmouth]] and [[Greenway Estate|Greenway]].<ref name="Simplon">{{cite web| author=Boyfrom le, I| url=http://www.simplonpc.co.uk/GreenwayFerry.html#TheFairmile.html| title=Greenway Ferry| publisher=Simplon Postcards| access-date=6 November 2009}}</ref> In May 2013, she was returned to her original wartime appearance. Torbay's "ferry wars"{{clarify}}} forced her removal from service,<ref>{{Cite web |title=Torbay ferry wars scupper service |url=http://www.torquayheraldexpress.co.uk/Bay-ferry-wars-scupper-service/story-26899092-detail/story.html |work=[[Torquay Herald Express]] |access-date= 20 December 2015 }}</ref> and in December 2015, RML ''497'' was acquired by the [[National Museum of the Royal Navy]].
'''RML ''497''''' (Rescue Motor Launch number 497<ref name="GreenwayProject">{{cite web|url=http://greenwayferry.co.uk/2012/2013/04/19/fairmile-rml497-project-western-lady-iii/|title=Fairmile B – RML497 – Project|date=19 April 2013|publisher=Greenway Ferry Pleasure Cruises|access-date=5 May 2013}}</ref>) is a former [[Royal Navy]] [[Fairmile B motor launch]] from [[World War II]]. She was named '''''Western Lady III''''' on her entry to civilian service, as a passenger motor vessel for [[Western Lady Ferry Service]]. From 2009<ref>{{Cite web |title=Back in port – the 'Lady' who 'should never have left' |url=http://www.torquayheraldexpress.co.uk/port-8212-Lady-left/story-12350835-detail/story.html |work=Torquay Herald Express |access-date=20 December 2015}}</ref> to 2015, she operated as '''''The Fairmile''''' for [[Greenway Ferry]] on their day cruise route from [[Torquay]] and [[Brixham]] to [[Dartmouth, Devon|Dartmouth]] and [[Greenway Estate|Greenway]].<ref name="Simplon">{{cite web| author=Boyfrom le, I| url=http://www.simplonpc.co.uk/GreenwayFerry.html#TheFairmile.html| title=Greenway Ferry| publisher=Simplon Postcards| access-date=6 November 2009}}</ref> In May 2013, she was returned to her original wartime appearance. Torbay's "ferry wars"{{clarify|date=February 2026}}} forced her removal from service,<ref>{{Cite web |title=Torbay ferry wars scupper service |url=http://www.torquayheraldexpress.co.uk/Bay-ferry-wars-scupper-service/story-26899092-detail/story.html |work=[[Torquay Herald Express]] |access-date= 20 December 2015 }}</ref> and in December 2015, RML ''497'' was acquired by the [[National Museum of the Royal Navy]].

== [[Draft:Ligobubfanu|Ligobubfanu]] moved to draftspace ==

Thanks for your contributions to [[Draft:Ligobubfanu|Ligobubfanu]]. Unfortunately, I do not think it is ready for publishing at this time because '''it needs more sources to establish notability'''.
I have converted your article to a draft which you can improve, undisturbed for a while.

Please see more information at [[Help:Unreviewed new page]].
When the article is ready for publication, please click on the "Submit the draft for review!" button at the top of the page OR move the page back. [[User:Ultraodan|Ultraodan]] ([[User talk:Ultraodan|talk]]) 01:44, 8 November 2025 (UTC)
::Then in that case: why is the articles [[Anulap]] and [[Lugeilan]] also moved to draft space for the same reason? They, and most other articles on the Polynesian deities, have been of the same lenght for years. By moving the article to draft space, you will make its development dependent on one single author: me. If you leave it on open space, it will be available for milions of people, who can help develop it. Therefore, moving an article to draft space, isn inefficient, and in effect a nomination for deletion.--[[User:Aciram|Aciram]] ([[User talk:Aciram#top|talk]]) 01:49, 8 November 2025 (UTC)
:::Those two articles need work too, but moving to draft is only an option for new articles. I don't think any of the three articles meet notability requirements in their current state. Having this in draftspace before it is ready for mainspace still means anyone can work on it. It doesn't need to be made perfect, just needs to prove [[WP:N|notability]]. If that's something that can't be done, or you aren't able to do yourself, I recommend moving on to something else. [[User:Ultraodan|Ultraodan]] ([[User talk:Ultraodan|talk]]) 02:21, 8 November 2025 (UTC)
::::She was not a human, whose relevance need to be established. She was a goddess: part of a religion. That is notability in itself. You may delete it of course. It do believe that is a bad policy: the most efficient way to develop an article is to allow it to be open for the entire world to develop, instead of just one person. That is a policy that founded wikipedia. Happy deletion!--[[User:Aciram|Aciram]] ([[User talk:Aciram#top|talk]]) 02:26, 8 November 2025 (UTC)
:::::I disagree with the idea that leaving an article that isn't ready for articlespace there is beneficial but let's agree to disagree on that. Human, goddess or anything else, notability needs to be established. It's not a question of is this subject important or not, it's a question of if there are reliable sources talking about her. [[User:Ultraodan|Ultraodan]] ([[User talk:Ultraodan|talk]]) 02:55, 8 November 2025 (UTC)
:::::: {{ping|Aciram}} A valid reason for moving items from draft space to main space is because they were moved into draft without consent.... That's because it annoys our valuable contributors.... you are our most important resource. [[User:Victuallers|Victuallers]] ([[User talk:Victuallers|talk]]) 12:00, 8 November 2025 (UTC)
:::::::That is true. But you have to think would this article survive a deletion discussion in it's current state? [[User:Ultraodan|Ultraodan]] ([[User talk:Ultraodan|talk]]) 12:07, 8 November 2025 (UTC)
::::::::The question AfD asks is whether its notable, not about "its current state". I recently reviewed the draftification of [[Horizon accounting system]]. An article about probably the most famous accounting computer system in the world. It had a four night TV programme about it, the UK gov are paying billion pound damages, hundreds went to jail, two decades of newspaper articles about it. Mentioned on Wikipedia in several key articles, had a good list of references in a "start" article of importance to UK politics and Computing .... and it went to draftify. Where, as Aciram noted, - practically no one would see it. AfD is a valid route for testing judgement. [[User:Victuallers|Victuallers]] ([[User talk:Victuallers|talk]]) 16:16, 8 November 2025 (UTC)
==[[Wikipedia:Criteria for speedy deletion|Speedy deletion]] nomination of [[:Category:20th-century Danish women farmers]]==
[[File:Ambox warning pn.svg|48px|left|alt=|link=]]

A tag has been placed on [[:Category:20th-century Danish women farmers]] indicating that it is currently empty, and is not a [[:Category:Disambiguation categories|disambiguation category]], a [[:Category:Wikipedia soft redirected categories|category redirect]], under discussion at [[Wikipedia:Categories for discussion|Categories for discussion]], or a project category that by its nature may become empty on occasion. If it remains empty for seven days or more, it may be deleted under [[WP:CSD#C1|section C1 of the criteria for speedy deletion]].

If you think this page should not be deleted for this reason you may '''contest the nomination''' by [[:Category:20th-century Danish women farmers|visiting the page]] and removing the speedy deletion tag. <!-- Template:Db-catempty-notice --> <!-- Template:Db-csd-notice-custom --> <span style="font-family:Papyrus; color:#800080;">[[User:Liz|'''''L'''''iz]]</span> <sup style="font-family: Times New Roman; color: #006400;">[[Special:Contributions/Liz|'''''Read!''''']] [[User talk:Liz|'''''Talk!''''']]</sup> 06:23, 9 November 2025 (UTC)

Line 31: Line 31:
Shortly after the fall of Luoyang during the [[Disaster of Yongjia]], Han forces marched west to capture [[Chang'an]] in August or September 311 and captured the city from the Prince of Nanyang, [[Sima Mo]]. Chang'an remained under Han control for only a few months, as Jin loyalists in the [[Guanzhong]] region, led by the general, [[Jia Ya]] soon rose up and placed Chang'an under siege. On May or June 312, the Han prince, [[Liu Yao]] was defeated and evacuated the city with more than 80,000 people east to the Han capital, [[Linfen|Pingyang]].
Shortly after the fall of Luoyang during the [[Disaster of Yongjia]], Han forces marched west to capture [[Chang'an]] in August or September 311 and captured the city from the Prince of Nanyang, [[Sima Mo]]. Chang'an remained under Han control for only a few months, as Jin loyalists in the [[Guanzhong]] region, led by the general, [[Jia Ya]] soon rose up and placed Chang'an under siege. On May or June 312, the Han prince, [[Liu Yao]] was defeated and evacuated the city with more than 80,000 people east to the Han capital, [[Linfen|Pingyang]].


On 19 October, Jia Ya and his allies acclaimed Sima Chi, the nephew of the captured [[Emperor Huai of Jin]], as the new emperor. Chi, posthumously known as [[Emperor Min of Jin|Emperor Min]], was only 12 years old at the time. Real power was held by his generals, in particular Jia Ya, [[Yan Ding]], [[Qu Yun (Jin dynasty)|Qu Yun]] and [[Suo Chen]]. In the following months, Jia Ya was killed during a battle with the [[Lushuihu]] tribes, while Yan Ding was killed as part of a plot between Qu Yun and Suo Chen, thus leaving the emperor in the hands of the two men.
On 19 October, Jia Ya and his allies acclaimed Sima Chi, the nephew of the captured [[Emperor Huai of Jin]], as the new emperor. Chi, posthumously known as [[Emperor Min of Jin|Emperor Min]], was only 12 years old at the time. Real power was held by his generals, in particular Jia Ya, [[Yan Ding]], [[Qu Yun (Jin dynasty)|Qu Yun]] and [[Suo Chen]]. In the following months, Jia Ya was killed during a battle with the [[Lushuihu]] tribes, while Yan Ding was killed as part of a plot between Qu Yun and Suo Chen, thus leaving the emperor in the hands of the two men.<ref name=":3">{{Cite web |last=Theobald |first=Ulrich |title=Jin Mindi 晉愍帝 Sima Ye 司馬鄴 (www.chinaknowledge.de) |url=http://www.chinaknowledge.de/History/Division/personsjinmindi.html |access-date=2026-02-07 |website=www.chinaknowledge.de |language=en}}</ref>


== First invasion of Chang'an (313) ==
== First invasion of Chang'an (313) ==
In June 313, Liu Yao was ordered to attack Chang'an with [[Qiao Zhiming]] and [[Zhao Ran]]. In response, Qu Yun went out to set camp at Huangbai (黃白; northeast of [[Sanyuan County]], [[Shaanxi]]) while Liu Yao camped at Puban (蒲阪; present-day [[Yongji, Shanxi]]). Liu Yao battled Qu Yun several times at Huangbai and defeated him each time, prompting the Jin court to dispatch Suo Chen to reinforce him in September or October.
In June 313, Liu Yao was ordered to attack Chang'an with [[Qiao Zhiming]] and [[Zhao Ran]]. In response, Qu Yun went out to set camp at Huangbai (黃白; northeast of [[Sanyuan County]], [[Shaanxi]]) while Liu Yao camped at Puban (蒲阪; present-day [[Yongji, Shanxi]]). Liu Yao battled Qu Yun several times at Huangbai and defeated him each time, prompting the Jin court to dispatch Suo Chen to reinforce him in September or October.<ref name=":3" />


Zhao Ran speculated that the Jin had brought most of the soldiers out to fight, leaving Chang'an defenseless. Thus, he brought with him 5,000 elite cavalry to launch a night raid into Chang'an. His forces broke through the outer walls, forcing Emperor Min to hide in the Sheyan Tower (射鴈樓). He also set fire to the enemy barracks and killed or plundered more than a thousand people before withdrawing to the Xiaoyao Garden (逍遙園). When the Jin general, Qu Jian (麴鑒) brought 5,000 soldiers to rescue the capital, Zhao Ran retreated, enticing Qu Jian to pursue him. At Lingwu (零武; around present-day [[Xianyang]], Shaanxi), Qu Jian was met with Liu Yao, who dealt him a great defeat.
Zhao Ran speculated that the Jin had brought most of the soldiers out to fight, leaving Chang'an defenseless. Thus, he brought with him 5,000 elite cavalry to launch a night raid into Chang'an. His forces broke through the outer walls, forcing Emperor Min to hide in the Sheyan Tower (射鴈樓). He also set fire to the enemy barracks and killed or plundered more than a thousand people before withdrawing to the Xiaoyao Garden (逍遙園). When the Jin general, Qu Jian (麴鑒) brought 5,000 soldiers to rescue the capital, Zhao Ran retreated, enticing Qu Jian to pursue him. At Lingwu (零武; around present-day [[Xianyang]], Shaanxi), Qu Jian was met with Liu Yao, who dealt him a great defeat.
Line 61: Line 61:


== Aftermath ==
== Aftermath ==
On 11 December, Emperor Min came out of Chang'an on a goat cart with jade in his mouth and tied to a coffin. Accepting his surrender, Liu Yao burnt the coffin and retrieved the jade before sending him off to Pingyang.{{Sfn|Graff|2002|p=50}} On 18 December, Min arrived and bowed in submission before Liu Cong, which reportedly caused Qu Yun to prostrate and weep. For the scene he caused, Qu Yun was imprisoned, where he killed himself, while Suo Chen was executed in Pingyang's marketplace for his treachery. The now-former emperor was made a marquis, but also a personal servant for Liu Cong. In 7 February 318, in an attempt to kill the resolve of Jin forces fighting around Luoyang, Liu Cong ordered Emperor Min executed.<ref name=":0" />
On 11 December, Emperor Min came out of Chang'an on a goat cart with jade in his mouth and tied to a coffin. Accepting his surrender, Liu Yao burnt the coffin and retrieved the jade before sending him off to Pingyang.{{Sfn|Graff|2002|p=50}}<ref name=":3" /> On 18 December, Min arrived and bowed in submission before Liu Cong, which reportedly caused Qu Yun to prostrate and weep. For the scene he caused, Qu Yun was imprisoned, where he killed himself, while Suo Chen was executed in Pingyang's marketplace for his treachery. The now-former emperor was made a marquis, but also a personal servant for Liu Cong. In 7 February 318, in an attempt to kill the resolve of Jin forces fighting around Luoyang, Liu Cong ordered Emperor Min executed.<ref name=":0" />


In January 317, when Emperor Min's surrender became known to the Prince of Langya, [[Emperor Yuan of Jin|Sima Rui]] at [[Jiankang]], he initially declared that he was going to launch a northern expedition, but nothing came of it. On 27 March, Song Zhe, who survived the aftermath of the fall, arrived at Jiankang claiming that he received Emperor Min's edict which granted Sima Rui responsibility over every affair. Following the precedent of his ancestors, Sima Rui declared himself the Prince of Jin, and in April 318, after news of Min's death reached Jiankang, he ascended the throne, posthumously known as Emperor Yuan of Jin and officially moving the imperial court south of the [[Yangtze|Yangtze River]].{{Sfn|Graff|2002|p=50}}
In January 317, when Emperor Min's surrender became known to the Prince of Langya, [[Emperor Yuan of Jin|Sima Rui]] at [[Jiankang]], he initially declared that he was going to launch a northern expedition, but nothing came of it. On 27 March, Song Zhe, who survived the aftermath of the fall, arrived at Jiankang claiming that he received Emperor Min's edict which granted Sima Rui responsibility over every affair. Following the precedent of his ancestors, Sima Rui declared himself the Prince of Jin, and in April 318, after news of Min's death reached Jiankang, he ascended the throne, posthumously known as Emperor Yuan of Jin and officially moving the imperial court south of the [[Yangtze|Yangtze River]].{{Sfn|Graff|2002|p=50}}

source_payload.html:
Archiving 2 discussions from User talk:Aciram. (BOT)

New page

{{Talkarchive}}

== [[Draft:Ligobubfanu|Ligobubfanu]] moved to draftspace ==

Thanks for your contributions to [[Draft:Ligobubfanu|Ligobubfanu]]. Unfortunately, I do not think it is ready for publishing at this time because '''it needs more sources to establish notability'''.
I have converted your article to a draft which you can improve, undisturbed for a while.

Please see more information at [[Help:Unreviewed new page]].
When the article is ready for publication, please click on the "Submit the draft for review!" button at the top of the page OR move the page back. [[User:Ultraodan|Ultraodan]] ([[User talk:Ultraodan|talk]]) 01:44, 8 November 2025 (UTC)
::Then in that case: why is the articles [[Anulap]] and [[Lugeilan]] also moved to draft space for the same reason? They, and most other articles on the Polynesian deities, have been of the same lenght for years. By moving the article to draft space, you will make its development dependent on one single author: me. If you leave it on open space, it will be available for milions of people, who can help develop it. Therefore, moving an article to draft space, isn inefficient, and in effect a nomination for deletion.--[[User:Aciram|Aciram]] ([[User talk:Aciram#top|talk]]) 01:49, 8 November 2025 (UTC)
:::Those two articles need work too, but moving to draft is only an option for new articles. I don't think any of the three articles meet notability requirements in their current state. Having this in draftspace before it is ready for mainspace still means anyone can work on it. It doesn't need to be made perfect, just needs to prove [[WP:N|notability]]. If that's something that can't be done, or you aren't able to do yourself, I recommend moving on to something else. [[User:Ultraodan|Ultraodan]] ([[User talk:Ultraodan|talk]]) 02:21, 8 November 2025 (UTC)
::::She was not a human, whose relevance need to be established. She was a goddess: part of a religion. That is notability in itself. You may delete it of course. It do believe that is a bad policy: the most efficient way to develop an article is to allow it to be open for the entire world to develop, instead of just one person. That is a policy that founded wikipedia. Happy deletion!--[[User:Aciram|Aciram]] ([[User talk:Aciram#top|talk]]) 02:26, 8 November 2025 (UTC)
:::::I disagree with the idea that leaving an article that isn't ready for articlespace there is beneficial but let's agree to disagree on that. Human, goddess or anything else, notability needs to be established. It's not a question of is this subject important or not, it's a question of if there are reliable sources talking about her. [[User:Ultraodan|Ultraodan]] ([[User talk:Ultraodan|talk]]) 02:55, 8 November 2025 (UTC)
:::::: {{ping|Aciram}} A valid reason for moving items from draft space to main space is because they were moved into draft without consent.... That's because it annoys our valuable contributors.... you are our most important resource. [[User:Victuallers|Victuallers]] ([[User talk:Victuallers|talk]]) 12:00, 8 November 2025 (UTC)
:::::::That is true. But you have to think would this article survive a deletion discussion in it's current state? [[User:Ultraodan|Ultraodan]] ([[User talk:Ultraodan|talk]]) 12:07, 8 November 2025 (UTC)
::::::::The question AfD asks is whether its notable, not about "its current state". I recently reviewed the draftification of [[Horizon accounting system]]. An article about probably the most famous accounting computer system in the world. It had a four night TV programme about it, the UK gov are paying billion pound damages, hundreds went to jail, two decades of newspaper articles about it. Mentioned on Wikipedia in several key articles, had a good list of references in a "start" article of importance to UK politics and Computing .... and it went to draftify. Where, as Aciram noted, - practically no one would see it. AfD is a valid route for testing judgement. [[User:Victuallers|Victuallers]] ([[User talk:Victuallers|talk]]) 16:16, 8 November 2025 (UTC)
==[[Wikipedia:Criteria for speedy deletion|Speedy deletion]] nomination of [[:Category:20th-century Danish women farmers]]==
[[File:Ambox warning pn.svg|48px|left|alt=|link=]]

A tag has been placed on [[:Category:20th-century Danish women farmers]] indicating that it is currently empty, and is not a [[:Category:Disambiguation categories|disambiguation category]], a [[:Category:Wikipedia soft redirected categories|category redirect]], under discussion at [[Wikipedia:Categories for discussion|Categories for discussion]], or a project category that by its nature may become empty on occasion. If it remains empty for seven days or more, it may be deleted under [[WP:CSD#C1|section C1 of the criteria for speedy deletion]].

If you think this page should not be deleted for this reason you may '''contest the nomination''' by [[:Category:20th-century Danish women farmers|visiting the page]] and removing the speedy deletion tag. <!-- Template:Db-catempty-notice --> <!-- Template:Db-csd-notice-custom --> <span style="font-family:Papyrus; color:#800080;">[[User:Liz|'''''L'''''iz]]</span> <sup style="font-family: Times New Roman; color: #006400;">[[Special:Contributions/Liz|'''''Read!''''']] [[User talk:Liz|'''''Talk!''''']]</sup> 06:23, 9 November 2025 (UTC)

← Previous revision Revision as of 11:41, 7 February 2026
Line 4: Line 4:
[[Image:Bhagirathi and Alaknanda Confluence.jpg|thumb|The same confluence viewed from upstream at a different time; note the swirl of sediment from the Alaknanda River]]
[[Image:Bhagirathi and Alaknanda Confluence.jpg|thumb|The same confluence viewed from upstream at a different time; note the swirl of sediment from the Alaknanda River]]


In [[geography]], a '''confluence''' (also ''conflux'') occurs where two or more [[watercourse]]s join to form a single [[channel (geography)|channel]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/conflux|title=Conflux – Definition of conflux by Merriam-Webster|work=merriam-webster.com |date=4 August 2025 }}</ref> A confluence can occur in several configurations: at the point where a [[tributary]] joins a larger [[river]] ([[main stem]]); or where two streams meet to become the [[river source|source]] of a river of a new name (such as the confluence of the [[Monongahela River|Monongahela]] and [[Allegheny River|Allegheny]] rivers, forming the [[Ohio River]]); or where two separated channels of a river (forming a [[river island]]) rejoin downstream from their point of separation.
A '''confluence''' in geography (also ''conflux'') occurs where two or more [[watercourse]]s join to form a single [[channel (geography)|channel]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/conflux|title=Conflux – Definition of conflux by Merriam-Webster|work=merriam-webster.com |date=4 August 2025 }}</ref> A confluence can occur in several configurations: at the point where a [[tributary]] joins a larger [[river]] ([[main stem]]); or where two streams meet to become the [[river source|source]] of a river of a new name (such as the confluence of the [[Monongahela River|Monongahela]] and [[Allegheny River|Allegheny]] rivers, forming the [[Ohio River]]); or where two separated channels of a river (forming a [[river island]]) rejoin downstream from their point of separation.


==Scientific study==
==Scientific studies==
[[File:Mississippi near St-Louis normally and in flood 93.jpg|thumb|Confluence of the [[Mississippi River|Mississippi]], [[Missouri River|Missouri]], and [[Illinois River|Illinois]] rivers with normal water levels in 1991, and during a flood in 1993]]
[[File:Mississippi near St-Louis normally and in flood 93.jpg|thumb|Confluence of the [[Mississippi River|Mississippi]], [[Missouri River|Missouri]], and [[Illinois River|Illinois]] rivers with normal water levels in 1991, and during a flood in 1993]]
Confluences are studied in a variety of sciences. [[Hydrology]] studies the characteristic flow patterns of confluences and how they give rise to patterns of erosion, bars, and scour pools.<ref>A widely cited work is James L. Best (1986) The morphology of river channel confluences. ''Progress in Physical Geography'' 10:157–174. For work citing Best, see [https://scholar.google.com/scholar?cites=16553134579381758779&as_sdt=2005&sciodt=0,5&hl=en].</ref> The water flows and their consequences are often studied with [[mathematical model]]s.<ref>A recent contribution with review of earlier work is Laurent Schindfessel, Stéphan Creëlle and Tom De Mulder (2015) "Flow patterns in an open channel confluence with increasingly dominant tributary inflow," ''Water'' 7: 4724–4751; available on line.</ref> Confluences are relevant to the distribution of living organisms (i.e., [[ecology]]) as well; "the general pattern [downstream of confluences] of increasing stream flow and decreasing slopes drives a corresponding shift in habitat characteristics."<ref>Quoted from Beechie et al. (2012), who cite earlier work. Tim Beechie, John S. Richardson, [[Angela Gurnell|Angela M. Gurnell]], and Junjiro Negishi (2012) "Watershed processes, human impacts, and process-based restoration." In Philip Roni and Tim Beechie (eds.) (2012) ''Stream and Watershed Restoration: A Guide to Restoring Riverine Processes and Habitats'', John Wiley & Sons. Excerpts available on line at Google Books.</ref>
Confluences are studied in a variety of sciences. [[Hydrology]] studies the characteristic flow patterns of confluences and how they give rise to patterns of erosion, bars, and scour pools.<ref>A widely cited work is James L. Best (1986) The morphology of river channel confluences. ''Progress in Physical Geography'' 10:157–174. For work citing Best, see [https://scholar.google.com/scholar?cites=16553134579381758779&as_sdt=2005&sciodt=0,5&hl=en].</ref> The water flows and their consequences are often studied with [[mathematical model]]s.<ref>A recent contribution with review of earlier work is Laurent Schindfessel, Stéphan Creëlle and Tom De Mulder (2015) "Flow patterns in an open channel confluence with increasingly dominant tributary inflow," ''Water'' 7: 4724–4751; available on line.</ref> Confluences are relevant to the distribution of living organisms (i.e., [[ecology]]) as well; "the general pattern [downstream of confluences] of increasing stream flow and decreasing slopes drives a corresponding shift in habitat characteristics."<ref>Quoted from Beechie et al. (2012), who cite earlier work. Tim Beechie, John S. Richardson, [[Angela Gurnell|Angela M. Gurnell]], and Junjiro Negishi (2012) "Watershed processes, human impacts, and process-based restoration." In Philip Roni and Tim Beechie (eds.) (2012) ''Stream and Watershed Restoration: A Guide to Restoring Riverine Processes and Habitats'', John Wiley & Sons. Excerpts available on line at Google Books.</ref>
